citeinfo.origin: United States. Bureau of Transportation Statistics
citeinfo.title: United States Border Crossings, 2013
citeinfo.othercit: This data is created and maintained by the Customs and Border Protection (CBP), and spatially enhanced by BTS. The CBP also designated the port codes, names, and attributes.

descript.abstract: Border Crossing Ports are points of entry for land modes along the U.S. - Canadian and U.S.- Mexcian borders. The ports of entry are located in 15 states along the U.S. borders. The nominal scale of the data set is 1:1000,000 with a maximal positional error of +- 10 meters.
descript.purpose: This dataset is published by USDOT-RITA-BTS to display ports of entry and its associated data as an online mapping application.
descript.supplinf: Used for the interface of Border Crossing/Entry Data: http://www.bts.gov/programs/international/transborder/TBDR_BC/TBDR_BC_Index.html. This data is created and maintained by the Customs and Border Protection (CBP), and spatially enhanced by BTS. The CBP also designated the port codes, names, and attributes. For any questions regarding the CBP data, please contact (877) CBP-5511.

cntorgp.cntorg: Research and Innovative Technology Administration's Bureau of Transportation Statistics (RITA/BTS)

attracc.attraccr: The accuracy of the location data is very high. PortName and PortCode are extracted from the Census website: The link is: http://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/reference/codes/index.html Only 40% of data were converted from .csv files, others were from digitized manually using high resolution image as background (Google Earth).

procstep.procdesc: The creation of this geospatial data layer was completed by USDOT-RITA-BTS in November 2011 and updated in February 2013. Step 1: Convert textual data into shapefile using the ArcGIS function. Step 2: Export the shapefile into KML and display the ports on Google Earth. Each port was checked with road network and country bounderies. Corrections were made for the locations that are far from ports, then record their geographic coordinates. Step 3: Export KML file with port locations into shapefile using the third-party software. Then other attributes were added within ArcGIS.

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry.
Port Code
attr.attrdefs: Census Foreign Trade Division, The link is: http://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/reference/codes/index.html

attr.attrdef: Port Name
attr.attrdefs: Census Foreign Trade Division, The link is: http://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/reference/codes/index.html

attr.attrdef: U.S. State Abbreviation
Coustoms Port Name
attr.attrdefs: Since the Border Crossing/Entry data are reported at the U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) port level with unique port codes, a port name must be used to present the ports which are sharing the same port code (most cases) for the surrounding ports. For example, Buffalo-Niagara Falls (port code:0901) was selected to present four ports: Buffalo-Peace Bridge, Niagara Falls-Lewiston Bridge, Niagara Falls-Rainbow Bridge and Niagara Falls-Whirlpool Bridge. The U.S. Census Bureau maintains a list of Customs districts/ports, port codes and descriptions known as the Schedule D. The most recent Schedule D is available from the U.S. Census Bureau?s Foreign Trade Division at: http://www.census.gov/foreign-trade/schedules/d/dist2.txt.

attr.attrdef: A number that is a unique identifier for each border crossing
Year of the attribute data
Number of arriving trucks; does not include privately owned pick-up trucks.

A container (loaded) is any conveyance entering the U.S. used for commercial purposes, full or empty. In this case, it is the number of full or empty truck containers arriving at a port. This series includes containers moving as inbound shipments.

A container (empty) is any conveyance entering the U.S. used for commercial purposes, full or empty. In this case, it is the number of full or empty truck containers arriving at a port. This series includes containers moving as inbound shipments.
Number of arriving trains at a particular port.

A container (loaded) is any conveyance entering the U.S. used for commercial purposes, full or empty. In this case, it is the number of full or empty rail containers arriving at a port. This series includes containers moving as inbound shipments.

A container (empty) is any conveyance entering the U.S. used for commercial purposes, full or empty. In this case, it is the number of full or empty rail containers arriving at a port. This series includes containers moving as inbound shipments.
Number of passengers and crew arriving by train and requiring U.S. Customs processing.
Number of arriving buses at a particular port, whether or not they are carrying passengers.
Number of persons arriving by bus requiring U.S. Customs processing.

Number of privately owned vehicles (POVs) arriving at a particular port. Includes pick-up trucks, motorcycles, recreational vehicles, taxis, snowmobiles, ambulances, hearses, and other motorized private ground vehicles.

Passengers Crossing In Privately Owned Vehicles-Persons entering the United States at a particular port by private automobiles, pick-up trucks, motorcycles, recreational vehicles, taxis, ambulances, hearses, tractors, snowmobiles and other motorized private ground vehicles.
Class of the border port. 1 - Port of Entry, 2 - Other Crossing
State FIPS code

digtinfo.filedec: No compression applied. However, if using digital transfer online option, note access instructions.

stdorder.ordering: Call (202-366-DATA), or E-mail (answers@bts.gov) RITA/BTS to request the National Transportation Atlas Databases (NTAD) 2013 DVD. This and other RITA/BTS products may be ordered from the RITA/BTS Internet site (<http://www.bts.gov/programs/geographic_information_services/>).
